fig.label: Figure 3

caption.p: Sentinel general practitioner data-based representation of (A) seasonal RSV epidemics, (B) seasonal epidemic intensity levels determined by MEM and (C) average epidemic MEM curve, Netherlands, 2005/06–2016/17 (n = 767 RSV positive samples)

fig.p: MEM: moving epidemic method; RSV: respiratory syncytial virus.

A. Length and timing of the epidemic period per season (coloured horizontal lines) and the timing of the peak (black dots) obtained using two different methods: (i) 1.2% of total number of RSV positives per season and (ii) the MEM method with an optimised slope parameter of 1.4.

B. Heat map showing the five different levels of intensity given by the MEM method for each season: baseline (≤1 RSV diagnosis/week; green), low (2−6 RSV diagnoses/week; yellow), medium (7−15 RSV diagnoses/week; orange), high (16−23 RSV diagnoses/week; red) and very high (≥24 RSV diagnoses/week; purple).

C. Average epidemic curve over the overall study period given by the MEM method (MEM web application) with start (first week above pre-epidemic threshold, indicated with a red dot) and end (first week below post-epidemic threshold, indicated with a green dot) of the epidemic period and the three different intensity thresholds (medium, high, very high).
Note that for 2010 and 2016 week 1 is actually week 53 of 2009 and 2015 respectively, and week 2 actually is week 1 of 2010 and 2016 respectively.
